data.title: Sum of Alternating Squares
data.statement:
Welcome to the challenge <<Sum of Alternating Squares!>> In this coding exercise, you will be tasked with calculating the sum of a series composed of alternating sign squares. Your task is to compute the sum of a series consisting of alternating squares from <<1st>> up to the [[n]]<<th>> term.

The series is defined as follows:
<<1^2>> - <<2^2>> + <<3^2>> - <<4^2>> + ... + <<(n-1)^2>> - <<n^2>>

For example:

If [[n]] = {{3}}, the series would be <<1^2>> - <<2^2>> + <<3^2>>, resulting in a sum of <<6>>.
If [[n]] = {{5}}, the series would be <<1^2>> - <<2^2>> + <<3^2>> - <<4^2>> + <<5^2>>, leading to a sum of <<15>>.

To tackle this problem, consider the pattern of alternating signs and squares. Craft an algorithm that capitalizes on this pattern to compute the sum without explicitly generating each term.

You can assume that the input [[n]] will always be a positive integer.
data.inputDescription: A positive integer [[n]], representing the number of terms in the series.
data.outputDescription: An integer, representing the sum of the series up to the [[n]]<<th>> term.

Goal

Welcome to the challenge Sum of Alternating Squares! In this coding exercise, you will be tasked with calculating the sum of a series composed of alternating sign squares. Your task is to compute the sum of a series consisting of alternating squares from 1st up to the nth term.

The series is defined as follows:
1^2 - 2^2 + 3^2 - 4^2 + ... + (n-1)^2 - n^2

For example:

If n = 3, the series would be 1^2 - 2^2 + 3^2, resulting in a sum of 6.
If n = 5, the series would be 1^2 - 2^2 + 3^2 - 4^2 + 5^2, leading to a sum of 15.

To tackle this problem, consider the pattern of alternating signs and squares. Craft an algorithm that capitalizes on this pattern to compute the sum without explicitly generating each term.

You can assume that the input n will always be a positive integer.
Input
A positive integer n, representing the number of terms in the series.
Output
An integer, representing the sum of the series up to the nth term.
Constraints
1 ≤ n ≤ 10^4
Example
Input
1
Output
1
